id.desc: Component ID, not specified by default. If specified, it can be used to refer the component in option or API.

name.desc:
Series name used for displaying in [tooltip][0] and filtering with [legend][1], or updating data and configuration with setOption.

[0]: #tooltip
[1]: #legend

colorBy.desc:
>  Since > v5.2.0 The policy to take color from [option.color][0]. Valid values: 

* 'series': assigns the colors in the palette by series, so that all data in the same series are in the same color;
* 'data': assigns colors in the palette according to data items, with each data item using a different color.



[0]: #color

legendHoverLink.desc:
Whether to enable highlighting chart when [legend][0] is being hovered.

[0]: #legend

selectedMode.desc: Selected mode. It is enabled by default, and you may set it to be false to disabled it. Besides, it can be set to 'single' or 'multiple', for single selection and multiple selections.

selectedOffset.desc: The offset distance of selected sector.

clockwise.desc: Whether the layout of sectors of pie chart is clockwise.

startAngle.desc: The start angle, which range is [0, 360].

minAngle.desc: The minimum angle of sector (0 ~ 360). It prevents some sector from being too small when value is small, which will affect user interaction.

minShowLabelAngle.desc: If a sector is less than this angle (0 ~ 360), label and labelLine will not be displayed.

roseType.desc:
Whether to show as Nightingale chart, which distinguishs data through radius. There are 2 optional modes: 

* 'radius' Use central angle to show the percentage of data, radius to show data size.
* 'area' All the sectors will share the same central angle, the data size is shown only through radiuses.

avoidLabelOverlap.desc: Whether to enable the strategy to avoid labels overlap. Defaults to be enabled, which will move the label positions in the case of labels overlapping

stillShowZeroSum.desc: Whether to show sector when all data are zero.

cursor.desc: The mouse style when mouse hovers on an element, the same as cursor property in CSS.

zlevel.desc: zlevel value of all graphical elements in . zlevel is used to make layers with Canvas. Graphical elements with different zlevel values will be placed in different Canvases, which is a common optimization technique. We can put those frequently changed elements (like those with animations) to a separate zlevel. Notice that too many Canvases will increase memory cost, and should be used carefully on mobile phones to avoid crash. Canvases with bigger zlevel will be placed on Canvases with smaller zlevel.

z.desc: z value of all graphical elements in , which controls order of drawing graphical components. Components with smaller z values may be overwritten by those with larger z values. z has a lower priority to zlevel, and will not create new Canvas.

left.desc: Distance between pie chart component and the left side of the container. left value can be instant pixel value like 20; it can also be a percentage value relative to container width like '20%'; and it can also be 'left', 'center', or 'right'. If the left value is set to be 'left', 'center', or 'right', then the component will be aligned automatically based on position.

top.desc: Distance between pie chart component and the top side of the container. top value can be instant pixel value like 20; it can also be a percentage value relative to container width like '20%'; and it can also be 'top', 'middle', or 'bottom'. If the left value is set to be 'top', 'middle', or 'bottom', then the component will be aligned automatically based on position.

right.desc: Distance between pie chart component and the right side of the container. right value can be instant pixel value like 20; it can also be a percentage value relative to container width like '20%'. Adaptive by default.

bottom.desc: Distance between pie chart component and the bottom side of the container. bottom value can be instant pixel value like 20; it can also be a percentage value relative to container width like '20%'. Adaptive by default.

width.desc: Width of pie chart component. Adaptive by default.

height.desc: Height of pie chart component. Adaptive by default.

showEmptyCircle.desc: If display an placeholder circle when there is no data.

color. 

> Supports setting as solid color using > rgb(255,255,255)> , > rgba(255,255,255,1)> , > #fff> , etc. Also supports setting as gradient color and pattern fill, see [> option.color][0]>  for details 

[0]: #color

emptyCircleStyle.borderColor.desc: border color, whose format is similar to that of color.

emptyCircleStyle.borderWidth.desc: border width. No border when it is set to be 0. border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

emptyCircleStyle.borderType.desc:
border type. Possible values are: 

* 'solid'
* 'dashed'
* 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array][0] of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible. For example： 

    {
    
    borderType: [5, 10],
    
    borderDashOffset: 5
    }
    



[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray

emptyCircleStyle.borderDashOffset.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the line dash offset. With borderType , we can make the line style more flexible. Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset

emptyCircleStyle.borderCap.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are: 

* 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
* 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
* 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN [lineCap][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap

emptyCircleStyle.borderJoin.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet. Possible values are: 

* 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
* 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
* 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the borderMiterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN [lineJoin][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin

emptyCircleStyle.borderMiterLimit.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when borderJoin is set as miter. Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored. Refer to MDN [miterLimit][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit

emptyCircleStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as color.

emptyCircleStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

emptyCircleStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

emptyCircleStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

label.desc: Text label of pie chart, to explain some data information about graphic item like value, name and so on. label is placed under itemStyle in ECharts 2.x. In ECharts 3, to make the configuration structure flatter, labelis taken to be at the same level with itemStyle, and has emphasis as itemStyle does.

label.position.desc:
The position of label. **Options:*** 'outside' Outside of sectors of pie chart, which relates to corresponding sector through [visual guide line][0].
* 'inside' Inside the sectors of pie chart.
* 'inner' is the same with 'inside'.
* 'center' In the center of pie chart. See [pie-doughnut example][1]

label.rotate.desc:

* If number, means degree that labels are rotated. From -90 degree to 90 degree. The negative value represents clockwise.

Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when width is set.

label.rich.<style_name>.width.desc: Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor). Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding. width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice. Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

label.rich.<style_name>.height.desc: Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see backgroundColor). Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding. Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

label.alignTo.desc:
Label aligning policy. Valid only when position is 'outer'. Since ECharts v4.6.0, we provide 'labelLine' and 'edge' two extra valid alignTo values. 

* 'none' (default): label lines have fixed length as [labelLine.length][0] and [labelLine.length2][1].
* 'labelLine': aligning to the end of label lines and the length of the shortest horizontal label lines is configured by [labelLine.length2][1].
* 'edge': aligning to text and the distance between the edges of text and the viewport is configured by [label.edgeDistance][2].

暂时无法显示

[1]: #series-pie.labelLine.length2
[2]: #series-pie.label.edgeDistance

label.edgeDistance.desc:
The horizontal distance between text edges and viewport when [label.position][0] is 'outer' and [label.alignTo][1] is 'edge'. 暂时无法显示 In most cases, you need a small edgeDistance value like 10 for mobile devices to make sure more text can be shown instead of being .... But on larger resolutions, a percentage value should be applied so that the label lines won't be too long. If your chart is used in varied resolutions, it is advised to set [responsive design][2] for different resolutions.

labelLine.minTurnAngle.desc: Minimum turn angle between two segments of guide line to prevent unaesthetic display when angle is too small. Can be 0 - 180 degree.

labelLayout.x.desc: The x position of the label. Support absolute pixel values ​​or relative values ​​such as '20%'.

labelLayout.y.desc: The y position of the label. Support absolute pixel values ​​or relative values ​​such as '20%'.

labelLayout.dx.desc: The pixel offset of the label in the x direction. Can be used with x.

labelLayout.dy.desc: The pixel offset of the label in the y direction. Can be used with y

labelLayout.width.desc: The width of displayed label. Can be used with overflow to constraint the label in a fixed width

labelLayout.height.desc: The height of displayed label. Can be used with lineOverflow to constraint the label in a fixed height.

labelLayout.align.desc: The horizontal alignment of the label. Can be 'left', 'center', 'right'.

labelLayout.verticalAlign.desc: The vertical alignment of the label. Can be 'top', 'middle', 'bottom'.

labelLayout.fontSize.desc: The text size of the label.

labelLayout.draggable.desc: Whether to allow the user to adjust the position by dragging.

labelLayout.labelLinePoints.desc:
The array of the three points of the label guide line. The format is: 

    [[x, y], [x, y], [x, y]]
    

It is often used in pie charts to fine-tune the guide line that has been calculated. Usually not recommended to set it in other situations.

The style of the decal pattern. It works only if [aria.enabled][0] and [aria.decal.show][1] are both set to be true. If it is set to be 'none', no decal will be used.

[0]: #aria.enabled
[1]: #aria.decal.show

itemStyle.decal.symbol.desc:
The symbol type of the decal. If it is in the type of string[], it means the symbols are used one by one. Icon types provided by ECharts includes 'circle', 'rect', 'roundRect', 'triangle', 'diamond', 'pin', 'arrow', 'none' It can be set to an image with 'image://url' , in which URL is the link to an image, or dataURI of an image. An image URL example: 

    'image://http://xxx.xxx.xxx/a/b.png'
    

A dataURI example: 

    'image://data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAQAMQAAORHHOVSKudfOulrSOp3WOyDZu6QdvCchPGolfO0o/XBs/fNwfjZ0frl3/zy7////wAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACH5BAkAABAALAAAAAAQABAAAAVVICSOZGlCQAosJ6mu7fiyZeKqNKToQGDsM8hBADgUXoGAiqhSvp5QAnQKGIgUhwFUYLCVDFCrKUE1lBavAViFIDlTImbKC5Gm2hB0SlBCBMQiB0UjIQA7'
    

Icons can be set to arbitrary vector path via 'path://' in ECharts. As compared with a raster image, vector paths prevent jagging and blurring when scaled, and have better control over changing colors. The size of the vector icon will be adapted automatically. Refer to [SVG PathData][0] for more information about the format of the path. You may export vector paths from tools like Adobe For example:

[0]: http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG/paths.html#PathData

itemStyle.decal.symbolSize.desc: Range of values: 0 to 1, representing the size of symbol relative to decal.

itemStyle.decal.symbolKeepAspect.desc: Whether or not to keep the aspect ratio of the pattern.

itemStyle.decal.color.desc: For the color of the decal pattern, it is recommended to use a translucent color, which can be superimposed on the color of the series itself.

itemStyle.decal.backgroundColor.desc: The background color of the decal will be over the color of the series itself, under the decal pattern.

itemStyle.decal.dashArrayX.desc:
The basic pattern of the decal pattern is an infinite loop in the form of Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank both horizontally and vertically, respectively. By setting the length of each pattern and blank, complex pattern effects can be achieved. dashArrayX controls the horizontal pattern pattern. When its value is of type number or number[], it is similar to [SVG stroke-dasharray][0]. 

* If it is of type number, it means that the pattern and the blank space are of this value respectively. For example, 5 means the pattern with width 5 is displayed first, then 5 pixels empty, then the pattern with width 5 is displayed...
* In the case of number[] type, it means that the pattern and empty space are loops of an array of values. For example: [5, 10, 2, 6] means the pattern is 5 pixels wide, then 10 pixels empty, then the pattern is 2 pixels wide, then 6 pixels empty, then the pattern is 5 pixels wide...
* If of type (number | number[])[], it means that each row is a loop with an array of values for the pattern and blank space. For example: [10, [2, 5]] means that the first line will be 10 pixels by 10 pixels and empty space, the second line will be 2 pixels by 2 pixels and empty space, and the third line will be 10 pixels by 10 pixels and empty space...

This interface can be better understood with the following examples. 暂时无法显示

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray

itemStyle.decal.dashArrayY.desc:
The basic pattern of the decal pattern is an infinite loop in the form of Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank both horizontally and vertically, respectively. By setting the length of each pattern and blank, complex pattern effects can be achieved. dashArrayY controls the horizontal pattern pattern. Similar to [SVG stroke-dasharray][0]. 

* If it is a number type, it means the pattern and the blank are each of this value. For example, 5 means that the pattern with a height of 5 is displayed first, then 5 pixels empty, then the pattern with a height of 5 is displayed...
* In the case of number[] type, it means that the pattern and empty space are loops of sequential array values. For example: [5, 10, 2, 6] means the pattern is 5 pixels high, then 10 pixels empty, then the pattern is 2 pixels high, then 6 pixels empty, then the pattern is 5 pixels high...

This interface can be better understood with the following examples. 暂时无法显示

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray

itemStyle.decal.rotation.desc: The overall rotation angle (in radians) of the pattern, in the range from `-Math.

itemStyle.decal.maxTileWidth.desc: The upper limit of the width of the generated pattern before it is duplicated. Usually this value is not necessary, but you can try to increase it if you notice discontinuous seams in the pattern when it repeats.

itemStyle.decal.maxTileHeight.desc: The upper limit of the height of the generated pattern before it repeats. This value is usually not necessary to set, but you can try to increase it if you find that the pattern has discontinuous seams when it is repeated.

itemStyle.borderRadius.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To specify the roundness for corners of the sectors of the pie chart. It can be either a specific pixel value or a percentage value relative to the radius of the sector. 

* borderRadius: 10: means that both inner corner radius and outer corner radius are 10px.
* borderRadius: '20%': means that both inner corner radius is 20% of the inner radius of the pie and outer corner radius is 20% of the outer radius of the pie.
* borderRadius: [10, 20]: means that the inner corner radius is 10px and the outer corner radius is 20px.
* borderRadius: ['20%', '50%']: means that the inner corner radius is 20% of the inner radius of the pie and the outer corner radius is 50% of the outer radius of the pie.

emphasis.scale.desc: Whether to scale to highlight the data in emphasis state.

emphasis.scaleSize.desc:
Size of scale. Available when [emphasis.scale][0] is set true.

emphasis.focus.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 When the data is highlighted, whether to fade out of other data to focus the highlighted. The following configurations are supported: 

* 'none' Do not fade out other data, it's by default.
* 'self' Only focus (not fade out) the element of the currently highlighted data.

* 'series' Focus on all elements of the series which the currently highlighted data belongs to.

**Example:**    emphasis: {
        focus: 'series',
        blurScope: 'coordinateSystem'
    }

emphasis.labelLine.lineStyle.cap.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are: 

* 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
* 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
* 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN [lineCap][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap

emphasis.labelLine.lineStyle.join.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet. Possible values are: 

* 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
* 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
* 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the miterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN [lineJoin][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin

emphasis.labelLine.lineStyle.miterLimit.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when join is set as miter. Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored. Refer to MDN [miterLimit][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit

select.label.rich.<style_name>.width.desc: Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor). Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding. width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice. Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

select.label.rich.<style_name>.height.desc: Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see backgroundColor). center.desc:
Center position of Pie chart, the first of which is the horizontal position, and the second is the vertical position. Percentage is supported. When set in percentage, the item is relative to the container width, and the second item to the height. **Example:**    // Set to absolute pixel values
    center: [400, 300]
    // Set to relative percent
    center: ['50%', '50%']

radius.desc:
的半径。可以为如下类型：

* number：直接指定外半径值。
* string：例如，'20%'，表示外半径为可视区尺寸（容器高宽中较小一项）的 20% 长度。
* Array.<number|string>：数组的第一项是内半径，第二项是外半径。每一项遵从上述 number string 的描述。

seriesLayoutBy.desc:
When [dataset][0] is used, seriesLayoutBy specifies whether the column or the row of dataset is mapped to the series, namely, the series is "layout" on columns or rows. Optional values: 

* 'column': by default, the columns of dataset are mapped the series. In this case, each column represents a dimension.
* 'row'：the rows of dataset are mapped to the series. In this case, each row represents a dimension.

Check this [example][1].

[0]: #dataset
[1]: https://echarts.apache.org/examples/en/editor.html?c=dataset-series-layout-by

datasetIndex.desc:
If [series.data][0] is not specified, and [dataset][1] exists, the series will use dataset. datasetIndex specifies which dataset will be used.

[0]: #series.data
[1]: #dataset

dataGroupId.desc:
A groupID common to all data in the series. the groupID will be used to classify the data and determine how merge and split animations are performed in the universal transition animation. If you are using the [dataset][0] component to represent the data, it is recommended to use encode.itemGroupID to specify which dimension is encoded as the groupID.

[0]: #dataset

* 'inner' is the same with 'inside'.
* 'center' In the center of pie chart. See [pie-doughnut example][1]

data.labelLine.lineStyle.cap.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are: 

* 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
* 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
* 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN [lineCap][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap

data.labelLine.lineStyle.join.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet. Possible values are: 

* 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
* 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
* 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the miterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN [lineJoin][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin

data.labelLine.lineStyle.miterLimit.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when join is set as miter. Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored. Refer to MDN [miterLimit][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit

data.itemStyle.decal.desc:
The style of the decal pattern. It works only if [aria.enabled][0] and [aria.decal.show][1] are both set to be true. If it is set to be 'none', no decal will be used.

[0]: #aria.enabled
[1]: #aria.decal.show

data.itemStyle.decal.symbol.desc:
The symbol type of the decal. If it is in the type of string[], it means the symbols are used one by one. Icon types provided by ECharts includes 'circle', 'rect', 'roundRect', 'triangle', 'diamond', 'pin', 'arrow', 'none' It can be set to an image with 'image://url' , in which URL is the link to an image, or dataURI of an image. An image URL example: 

    'image://http://xxx.xxx.xxx/a/b.png'
    

A dataURI example: 

    'image://data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAQAMQAAORHHOVSKudfOulrSOp3WOyDZu6QdvCchPGolfO0o/XBs/fNwfjZ0frl3/zy7////wAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACH5BAkAABAALAAAAAAQABAAAAVVICSOZGlCQAosJ6mu7fiyZeKqNKToQGDsM8hBADgUXoGAiqhSvp5QAnQKGIgUhwFUYLCVDFCrKUE1lBavAViFIDlTImbKC5Gm2hB0SlBCBMQiB0UjIQA7'
    

Icons can be set to arbitrary vector path via 'path://' in ECharts. As compared with a raster image, vector paths prevent jagging and blurring when scaled, and have better control over changing colors. The size of the vector icon will be adapted automatically. Refer to [SVG PathData][0] for more information about the format of the path. You may export vector paths from tools like Adobe For example: 

    'path://M30.9,53.2C16.8,53.2,5.3,41.7,5.3,27.6S16.8,2,30.9,2C45,2,56.4,13.5,56.4,27.6S45,53.2,30.9,53.2z M30.9,3.5C17.6,3.5,6.8,14.4,6.8,27.6c0,13.3,10.8,24.1,24.101,24.1C44.2,51.7,55,40.9,55,27.6C54.9,14.4,44.1,3.5,30.9,3.5z M36.9,35.8c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H36c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1V35.8z M27.8,35.8 c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H27c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1L27.8,35.8L27.8,35.8z'
    

[0]: http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG/paths.html#PathData

data.itemStyle.decal.symbolSize.desc: Range of values: 0 to 1, representing the size of symbol relative to decal.

data.itemStyle.decal.symbolKeepAspect.desc: Whether or not to keep the aspect ratio of the pattern.

data.itemStyle.decal.color.desc: For the color of the decal pattern, it is recommended to use a translucent color, which can be superimposed on the color of the series itself.

data.itemStyle.decal.backgroundColor.desc: The background color of the decal will be over the color of the series itself, under the decal pattern.

data.itemStyle.decal.dashArrayX.desc:
The basic pattern of the decal pattern is an infinite loop in the form of Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank both horizontally and vertically, respectively. By setting the length of each pattern and blank, complex pattern effects can be achieved. dashArrayX controls the horizontal pattern pattern. When its value is of type number or number[], it is similar to [SVG stroke-dasharray][0]. 

* If it is of type number, it means that the pattern and the blank space are of this value respectively. For example, 5 means the pattern with width 5 is displayed first, then 5 pixels empty, then the pattern with width 5 is displayed...
* In the case of number[] type, it means that the pattern and empty space are loops of an array of values. For example: [5, 10, 2, 6] means the pattern is 5 pixels wide, then 10 pixels empty, then the pattern is 2 pixels wide, then 6 pixels empty, then the pattern is 5 pixels wide...
* If of type (number | number[])[], it means that each row is a loop with an array of values for the pattern and blank space. For example: [10, [2, 5]] means that the first line will be 10 pixels by 10 pixels and empty space, the second line will be 2 pixels by 2 pixels and empty space, and the third line will be 10 pixels by 10 pixels and empty space...

This interface can be better understood with the following examples. 暂时无法显示

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray

data.itemStyle.decal.dashArrayY.desc:
The basic pattern of the decal pattern is an infinite loop in the form of Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank both horizontally and vertically, respectively. By setting the length of each pattern and blank, complex pattern effects can be achieved. dashArrayY controls the horizontal pattern pattern. Similar to [SVG stroke-dasharray][0]. 

* If it is a number type, it means the pattern and the blank are each of this value. For example, 5 means that the pattern with a height of 5 is displayed first, then 5 pixels empty, then the pattern with a height of 5 is displayed...
* In the case of number[] type, it means that the pattern and empty space are loops of sequential array values. For example: [5, 10, 2, 6] means the pattern is 5 pixels high, then 10 pixels empty, then the pattern is 2 pixels high, then 6 pixels empty, then the pattern is 5 pixels high...

This interface can be better understood with the following examples. 暂时无法显示

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray

data.itemStyle.decal.rotation.desc: The overall rotation angle (in radians) of the pattern, in the range from `-Math.

data.itemStyle.decal.maxTileWidth.desc: The upper limit of the width of the generated pattern before it is duplicated. Usually this value is not necessary, but you can try to increase it if you notice discontinuous seams in the pattern when it repeats.

data.itemStyle.decal.maxTileHeight.desc: The upper limit of the height of the generated pattern before it repeats. This value is usually not necessary to set, but you can try to increase it if you find that the pattern has discontinuous seams when it is repeated.

data.itemStyle.borderRadius.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To specify the roundness for corners of the sectors of the pie chart. It can be either a specific pixel value or a percentage value relative to the radius of the sector. 

* borderRadius: 10: means that both inner corner radius and outer corner radius are 10px.
* borderRadius: '20%': means that both inner corner radius is 20% of the inner radius of the pie and outer corner radius is 20% of the outer radius of the pie.
* borderRadius: [10, 20]: means that the inner corner radius is 10px and the outer corner radius is 20px.
* borderRadius: ['20%', '50%']: means that the inner corner radius is 20% of the inner radius of the pie and the outer corner radius is 50% of the outer radius of the pie.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset

data.emphasis.labelLine.lineStyle.cap.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are: 

* 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
* 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
* 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN [lineCap][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap

data.emphasis.labelLine.lineStyle.join.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet. Possible values are: 

* 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
* 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
* 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the miterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN [lineJoin][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin

data.emphasis.labelLine.lineStyle.miterL.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when join is set as miter. Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored. Refer to MDN [miterLimit][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit

data.emphasis.labelLine.lineStyle.shadow.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as color.
Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.
Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

data.emphasis.labelLine.lineStyle.opacit.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

data.emphasis.itemStyle.color.desc:
color. Since 5.2.0, it can be set to 'inherit' in the emphasis state to disable color highlight. 

> Supports setting as solid color using > rgb(255,255,255)> , > rgba(255,255,255,1)> , > #fff> , etc. Also supports setting as gradient color and pattern fill, see [> option.color][0]>  for details 

[0]: #color

data.emphasis.itemStyle.borderColor.desc: border color, whose format is similar to that of color.

data.emphasis.itemStyle.borderWidth.desc: border width. No border when it is set to be 0. border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

data.emphasis.itemStyle.borderType.desc:
border type. Possible values are: 

* 'solid'
* 'dashed'
* 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array][0] of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible. For example： 

    {
    
    borderType: [5, 10],
    
    borderDashOffset: 5
    }
    



[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray

data.emphasis.itemStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as color.

data.emphasis.itemStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

data.emphasis.itemStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

data.emphasis.itemStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

data.emphasis.itemStyle.borderRadius.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To specify the roundness for corners of the sectors of the pie chart. It can be either a specific pixel value or a percentage value relative to the radius of the sector. 

* borderRadius: 10: means that both inner corner radius and outer corner radius are 10px.
* borderRadius: '20%': means that both inner corner radius is 20% of the inner radius of the pie and outer corner radius is 20% of the outer radius of the pie.
* borderRadius: [10, 20]: means that the inner corner radius is 10px and the outer corner radius is 20px.
* borderRadius: ['20%', '50%']: means that the inner corner radius is 20% of the inner radius of the pie and the outer corner radius is 50% of the outer radius of the pie.

data.blur.label.rotate.desc:
Label rotation. 

* If true, layout label radically.
* If number, means degree that labels are rotated. From -90 degree to 90 degree. The negative value represents clockwise.

data.blur.label.overflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when width is set. 

* 'truncate' Truncate the text and trailing with ellipsis.
* 'break' Break by word
* 'breakAll' Break by character.

data.blur.label.ellipsis.desc: Ellipsis to be displayed when overflow is set to truncate.

data.blur.label.lineOverflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow on height. 

* 'truncate' Truncate the overflow lines.

data.blur.label.rich.<style_name>.width.desc: Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor). Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding. width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice. Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

data.blur.label.rich.<style_name>.height.desc: Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see backgroundColor). Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding. Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

data.select.labelLine.lineStyle.cap.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are: 

* 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
* 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
* 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN [lineCap][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap

data.select.labelLine.lineStyle.join.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet. Possible values are: 

* 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
* 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
* 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the miterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN [lineJoin][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit

data.select.itemStyle.borderRadius.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To specify the roundness for corners of the sectors of the pie chart. It can be either a specific pixel value or a percentage value relative to the radius of the sector. 

* borderRadius: 10: means that both inner corner radius and outer corner radius are 10px.
* borderRadius: '20%': means that both inner corner radius is 20% of the inner radius of the pie and outer corner radius is 20% of the outer radius of the pie.
* borderRadius: [10, 20]: means that the inner corner radius is 10px and the outer corner radius is 20px.
* borderRadius: ['20%', '50%']: means that the inner corner radius is 20% of the inner radius of the pie and the outer corner radius is 50% of the outer radius of the pie.

data.tooltip.desc: tooltip settings in this series data.

data.tooltip.position.desc:
提示框浮层的位置，默认不设置时位置会跟随鼠标的位置。

可选：

* Array

通过数组表示提示框浮层的位置，支持数字设置绝对位置，百分比设置相对位置。

示例:
```javascript
// 绝对位置，相对于容器左侧 10px, 上侧 10 px
position: [10, 10]
// 相对位置，放置在容器正中间
position: ['50%', '50%']
```

* Function

回调函数，格式如下：

```javascript
(point: Array, params: Object|Array.<Object>, dom: HTMLDomElement, rect: Object, size: Object) => Array
```

**参数**
point: 鼠标位置，如 [20, 40]。
params: 同 formatter 的参数相同。
dom: tooltip 的 dom 对象。
rect: 只有鼠标在图形上时有效，是一个用 x , y , width , height四个属性表达的图形包围盒。
size: 包括 dom 的尺寸和 echarts 容器的当前尺寸，例如：{contentSize: [width, height], viewSize: [width, height]}。

**返回值：**
可以是一个表示 tooltip 位置的数组，数组值可以是绝对的像素值，也可以是相 百分比。
也可以是一个对象，如：{left: 10, top: 30}，或者 {right: '20%', bottom: 40}。

如下示例：

```javascript
position: function (point, params, dom, rect, size) {
    // 固定在顶部
    return [point[0], '10%'];
}
```

或者：

```javascript
position: function (pos, params, dom, rect, size) {
    // 鼠标在左侧时 tooltip 显示到右侧，鼠标在右侧时 tooltip 显示到左侧。
    var obj = {top: 60};
    obj[['left', 'right'][+(pos[0] < size.viewSize[0] / 2)]] = 5;
    return obj;
}
```

* 'inside'
    鼠标所在图形的内部中心位置，只在 trigger 为 'item' 的时候有效。

* 'top'
    鼠标所在图形上侧，只在 trigger 为 'item' 的时候有效。

* 'left'
    鼠标所在图形左侧，只在 trigger 为 'item' 的时候有效。

* 'right'
    鼠标所在图形右侧，只在 trigger 为 'item' 的时候有效。

* 'bottom'
    鼠标所在图形底侧，只在 trigger 为 'item' 的时候有效。

markPoint.symbol.desc:
Symbol of . Icon types provided by ECharts includes 'circle', 'rect', 'roundRect', 'triangle', 'diamond', 'pin', 'arrow', 'none' It can be set to an image with 'image://url' , in which URL is the link to an image, or dataURI of an image. An image URL example: 

    'image://http://xxx.xxx.xxx/a/b.png'
    

A dataURI example: 

    'image://data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAQAMQAAORHHOVSKudfOulrSOp3WOyDZu6QdvCchPGolfO0o/XBs/fNwfjZ0frl3/zy7////wAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACH5BAkAABAALAAAAAAQABAAAAVVICSOZGlCQAosJ6mu7fiyZeKqNKToQGDsM8hBADgUXoGAiqhSvp5QAnQKGIgUhwFUYLCVDFCrKUE1lBavAViFIDlTImbKC5Gm2hB0SlBCBMQiB0UjIQA7'
    

Icons can be set to arbitrary vector path via 'path://' in ECharts. As compared with a raster image, vector paths prevent jagging and blurring when scaled, and have better control over changing colors. The size of the vector icon will be adapted automatically. Refer to [SVG PathData][0] for more information about the format of the path. You may export vector paths from tools like Adobe For example: 

    'path://M30.9,53.2C16.8,53.2,5.3,41.7,5.3,27.6S16.8,2,30.9,2C45,2,56.4,13.5,56.4,27.6S45,53.2,30.9,53.2z M30.9,3.5C17.6,3.5,6.8,14.4,6.8,27.6c0,13.3,10.8,24.1,24.101,24.1C44.2,51.7,55,40.9,55,27.6C54.9,14.4,44.1,3.5,30.9,3.5z M36.9,35.8c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H36c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1V35.8z M27.8,35.8 c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H27c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1L27.8,35.8L27.8,35.8z'
    

If symbols needs to be different, you can set with callback function in the following format: 

    (value: Array|number, params: Object) => string
    

The first parameter value is the value in [data][1], and the second parameter params is the rest parameters of data item.

[0]: http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG/paths.html#PathData
[1]: #series-pie.data

markPoint.symbolSize.desc:
symbol size. It can be set to single numbers like 10, or use an array to represent width and height. For example, [20, 10] means symbol width is 20, and height is10. If size of symbols needs to be different, you can set with callback function in the following format: 

    (value: Array|number, params: Object) => number|Array
    

The first parameter value is the value in [data][0], and the second parameter params is the rest parameters of data item.

[0]: #series-pie.data

markPoint.symbolRotate.desc:
Rotate degree of symbol. The negative value represents clockwise. Note that when symbol is set to be 'arrow' in markLine, symbolRotate value will be ignored, and compulsively use tangent angle. If rotation of symbols needs to be different, you can set with callback function in the following format: 

    (value: Array|number, params: Object) => number
    

The first parameter value is the value in [data][0], and the second parameter params is the rest parameters of data item. 

> Callback is supported since 4.8.0 . 

[0]: #series-pie.data

markPoint.symbolKeepAspect.desc: Whether to keep aspect for symbols in the form of path://.

markPoint.symbolOffset.desc: Offset of symbol relative to original position. By default, symbol will be put in the center position of data. But if symbol is from user-defined vector path or image, you may not expect symbol to be in center. In this case, you may use this attribute to set offset to default position. It can be in absolute pixel value, or in relative percentage value. For example, [0, '-50%'] means to move upside side position of symbol height. It can be used to make the arrow in the bottom to be at data position when symbol is pin.

markPoint.silent.desc: Whether to ignore mouse events. Default value is false, for triggering and responding to mouse events.

markPoint.label.position.desc:
Label position. **Followings are the options:*** [x, y] Use relative percentage, or absolute pixel values to represent position of label relative to top-left corner of bounding box. For example: 

      // Absolute pixel values
      position: [10, 10],
      // Relative percentage
      position: ['50%', '50%']

markPoint.label.rich.<style_name>.width.desc: Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor). Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding. width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice. Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

markPoint.itemStyle.borderColor.desc: border color, whose format is similar to that of color.

markPoint.itemStyle.borderWidth.desc: border width. No border when it is set to be 0. border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

markPoint.itemStyle.borderType.desc:
border type. Possible values are: 

* 'solid'
* 'dashed'
* 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array][0] of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible. For example：

    borderType: [5, 10],
    
    borderDashOffset: 5
    }
    



[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray

markPoint.itemStyle.borderDashOffset.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the line dash offset. With borderType , we can make the line style more flexible. Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset

markPoint.itemStyle.borderCap.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are: 

* 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
* 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
* 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN [lineCap][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap

markPoint.itemStyle.borderJoin.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet. Possible values are: 

* 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
* 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
* 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the borderMiterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN [lineJoin][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin

markPoint.itemStyle.borderMiterLimit.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when borderJoin is set as miter. Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored. Refer to MDN [miterLimit][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit

markPoint.itemStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

      position: ['50%', '50%']

* 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the borderMiterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN [lineJoin][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin

markPoint.blur.itemStyle.borderMiterLimi.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when borderJoin is set as miter. Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored. Refer to MDN [miterLimit][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit

markPoint.blur.itemStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as color.

markPoint.blur.itemStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

markPoint.blur.itemStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

markPoint.blur.itemStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

markPoint.data.desc:
Data array for mark points, each of which is an object. Here are some ways to assign mark point position. 

1. Assign coordinate according to container with [x][0], [y][1] attribute, in which pixel values and percentage are supported.

When multiple attributes exist, priority is as the above order. **For example:**    data: [
    
        {
            name: 'screen coordinate',
            x: 100,
            y: 100
        }
    ]
    



[0]: #series-pie.markPoint.data.x
[1]: #series-pie.markPoint.data.y

markPoint.data.x.desc: X position according to container, in pixel.

markPoint.data.y.desc: Y position according to container, in pixel.

markPoint.data.value.desc: Label value, which can be ignored.

markPoint.data.symbol.desc:
Symbol of . Icon types provided by ECharts includes 'circle', 'rect', 'roundRect', 'triangle', 'diamond', 'pin', 'arrow', 'none' It can be set to an image with 'image://url' , in which URL is the link to an image, or dataURI of an image. An image URL example: 

    'image://http://xxx.xxx.xxx/a/b.png'
    

A dataURI example: 

    'image://data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAQAMQAAORHHOVSKudfOulrSOp3WOyDZu6QdvCchPGolfO0o/XBs/fNwfjZ0frl3/zy7////wAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACH5BAkAABAALAAAAAAQABAAAAVVICSOZGlCQAosJ6mu7fiyZeKqNKToQGDsM8hBADgUXoGAiqhSvp5QAnQKGIgUhwFUYLCVDFCrKUE1lBavAViFIDlTImbKC5Gm2hB0SlBCBMQiB0UjIQA7'
    

Icons can be set to arbitrary vector path via 'path://' in ECharts. As compared with a raster image, vector paths prevent jagging and blurring when scaled, and have better control over changing colors. The size of the vector icon will be adapted automatically. Refer to [SVG PathData][0] for more information about the format of the path. You may export vector paths from tools like Adobe For example: 

    'path://M30.9,53.2C16.8,53.2,5.3,41.7,5.3,27.6S16.8,2,30.9,2C45,2,56.4,13.5,56.4,27.6S45,53.2,30.9,53.2z M30.9,3.5C17.6,3.5,6.8,14.4,6.8,27.6c0,13.3,10.8,24.1,24.101,24.1C44.2,51.7,55,40.9,55,27.6C54.9,14.4,44.1,3.5,30.9,3.5z M36.9,35.8c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H36c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1V35.8z M27.8,35.8 c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H27c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1L27.8,35.8L27.8,35.8z'
    

[0]: http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG/paths.html#PathData

markPoint.data.symbolSize.desc: symbol size. It can be set to single numbers like 10, or use an array to represent width and height. For example, [20, 10] means symbol width is 20, and height is10.

markPoint.data.symbolRotate.desc: Rotate degree of symbol. The negative value represents clockwise. Note that when symbol is set to be 'arrow' in markLine, symbolRotate value will be ignored, and compulsively use tangent angle.

markPoint.data.symbolKeepAspect.desc: Whether to keep aspect for symbols in the form of path://.

markPoint.data.symbolOffset.desc: Offset of symbol relative to original position. By default, symbol will be put in the center position of data. But if symbol is from user-defined vector path or image, you may not expect symbol to be in center. In this case, you may use this attribute to set offset to default position. It can be in absolute pixel value, or in relative percentage value. For example, [0, '-50%'] means to move upside side position of symbol height. It can be used to make the arrow in the bottom to be at data position when symbol is pin.

color.

markPoint.data.itemStyle.borderWidth.desc: border width. No border when it is set to be 0. border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

border type. Possible values are: 

* 'solid'
* 'dashed'
* 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array][0] of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible. For example：

    borderDashOffset: 5

markPoint.data.itemStyle.borderCap.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are: 

* 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
* 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
* 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN [lineCap][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap

markPoint.data.itemStyle.borderJoin.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet. Possible values are: 

* 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
* 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
* 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the borderMiterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN [lineJoin][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin

markPoint.data.itemStyle.borderMiterLimi.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when borderJoin is set as miter. Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored. Refer to MDN [miterLimit][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit

      position: ['50%', '50%']

markPoint.data.label.rich.<style_name>.w.desc: Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor). Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding. width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice. Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset

>  Since > v5.0.0 To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are: 

* 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
* 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
* 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN [lineCap][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap

>  Since > v5.0.0 To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet. Possible values are: 

* 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
* 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
* 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the borderMiterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN [lineJoin][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin

>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when borderJoin is set as miter. Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored. Refer to MDN [miterLimit][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit

markLine.label.rich.<style_name>.width.desc: Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor). Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding. width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice. Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

markLine.blur.label.color.desc: text color. If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

markLine.blur.label.borderColor.desc: Border color of the text fragment. If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

markLine.blur.label.borderWidth.desc: Border width of the text fragment.

markLine.blur.label.borderType.desc:
the text fragment border type. Possible values are: 

* 'solid'
* 'dashed'
* 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array][0] of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible. For example： 

    {
    
    borderType: [5, 10],
    
    borderDashOffset: 5
    }
    



[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray

markLine.blur.label.borderDashOffset.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the line dash offset. With borderType , we can make the line style more flexible. Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset

markLine.blur.label.borderRadius.desc: Border radius of the text fragment.

markLine.blur.label.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example: 

* padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]: represents padding of [top, right, bottom, left].
* padding: 4: represents padding: [4, 4, 4, 4].
* padding: [3, 4]: represents padding: [3, 4, 3, 4].

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

markLine.blur.label.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color of the text block.

markLine.blur.label.shadowBlur.desc: Show blur of the text block.

markLine.blur.label.shadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.

markLine.blur.label.shadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text block.

markLine.blur.label.textBorderColor.desc: Storke color of the text. If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

markLine.blur.label.textBorderWidth.desc: Storke line width of the text.

markLine.blur.label.textShadowColor.desc: Shadow color of the text itself.

markLine.blur.label.textShadowBlur.desc: Shadow blue of the text itself.

markLine.blur.label.textShadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text itself.

markLine.blur.label.textShadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text itself.

markLine.blur.label.overflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when width is set. 

* 'truncate' Truncate the text and trailing with ellipsis.
* 'break' Break by word
* 'breakAll' Break by character.

markLine.blur.label.ellipsis.desc: Ellipsis to be displayed when overflow is set to truncate.

markLine.blur.label.lineOverflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow on height. 

* 'truncate' Truncate the overflow lines.

markLine.blur.label.rich.<style_name>.sh.desc: Shadow color of the text block.

markLine.blur.label.rich.<style_name>.wi.desc: Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor). Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding. width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice. Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

markLine.blur.label.rich.<style_name>.he.desc: Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see backgroundColor). Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding. Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

markLine.blur.lineStyle.cap.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are: 

* 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
* 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
* 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN [lineCap][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap

markLine.blur.lineStyle.join.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet. Possible values are: 

* 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
* 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
* 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the miterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN [lineJoin][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin

markLine.blur.lineStyle.miterLimit.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when join is set as miter. Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored. Refer to MDN [miterLimit][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit

markLine.blur.lineStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

markLine.blur.lineStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

markLine.data.0.name.desc: Name of the marker, which will display as a label.

markLine.data.0.x.desc: X position according to container, in pixel.

markLine.data.0.y.desc: Y position according to container, in pixel.

markLine.data.0.value.desc: Label value, which can be ignored.

markLine.data.0.symbol.desc:
Symbol of starting point. Icon types provided by ECharts includes 'circle', 'rect', 'roundRect', 'triangle', 'diamond', 'pin', 'arrow', 'none' It can be set to an image with 'image://url' , in which URL is the link to an image, or dataURI of an image. An image URL example: 

    'image://http://xxx.xxx.xxx/a/b.png'
    

A dataURI example: 

    'image://data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAQAMQAAORHHOVSKudfOulrSOp3WOyDZu6QdvCchPGolfO0o/XBs/fNwfjZ0frl3/zy7////wAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACH5BAkAABAALAAAAAAQABAAAAVVICSOZGlCQAosJ6mu7fiyZeKqNKToQGDsM8hBADgUXoGAiqhSvp5QAnQKGIgUhwFUYLCVDFCrKUE1lBavAViFIDlTImbKC5Gm2hB0SlBCBMQiB0UjIQA7'
    

Icons can be set to arbitrary vector path via 'path://' in ECharts. As compared with a raster image, vector paths prevent jagging and blurring when scaled, and have better control over changing colors. The size of the vector icon will be adapted automatically. Refer to [SVG PathData][0] for more information about the format of the path. You may export vector paths from tools like Adobe For example: 

    'path://M30.9,53.2C16.8,53.2,5.3,41.7,5.3,27.6S16.8,2,30.9,2C45,2,56.4,13.5,56.4,27.6S45,53.2,30.9,53.2z M30.9,3.5C17.6,3.5,6.8,14.4,6.8,27.6c0,13.3,10.8,24.1,24.101,24.1C44.2,51.7,55,40.9,55,27.6C54.9,14.4,44.1,3.5,30.9,3.5z M36.9,35.8c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H36c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1V35.8z M27.8,35.8 c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H27c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1L27.8,35.8L27.8,35.8z'
    

[0]: http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG/paths.html#PathData

markLine.data.0.symbolSize.desc: starting point symbol size. It can be set to single numbers like 10, or use an array to represent width and height. For example, [20, 10] means symbol width is 20, and height is10.

markLine.data.0.symbolRotate.desc: Rotate degree of starting point symbol. The negative value represents clockwise. Note that when symbol is set to be 'arrow' in markLine, symbolRotate value will be ignored, and compulsively use tangent angle.

markLine.data.0.symbolKeepAspect.desc: Whether to keep aspect for symbols in the form of path://.

markLine.data.0.symbolOffset.desc: Offset of starting point symbol relative to original position. By default, symbol will be put in the center position of data. But if symbol is from user-defined vector path or image, you may not expect symbol to be in center. In this case, you may use this attribute to set offset to default position. It can be in absolute pixel value, or in relative percentage value. For example, [0, '-50%'] means to move upside side position of symbol height. It can be used to make the arrow in the bottom to be at data position when symbol is pin.

markLine.data.0.lineStyle.desc: Line style of this data item, which will be merged with lineStyle of starting point and ending point.

markLine.data.0.label.position.desc:
Positions of labels can be: 

* 'start' starting point of the line.
* 'middle' middle point of the line.
* 'end' ending point of the line.

Since version 4.7.0, more label positions are supported: 'start', 'middle', 'end', 'insideStartTop', 'insideStartBottom', 'insideMiddleTop', 'insideMiddleBottom', 'insideEndTop', 'insideEndBottom'. 'insideMiddleBottom' is the same as 'middle'. Position is as the following chart. The distance between labels and mark lines can be set with [label.distance][0]. 暂时无法显示

markLine.data.0.emphasis.lineStyle.cap.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are: 

* 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
* 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
* 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN [lineCap][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap

markLine.data.0.emphasis.lineStyle.join.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet. Possible values are: 

* 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
* 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
* 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the miterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN [lineJoin][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin

markLine.data.0.emphasis.lineStyle.miter.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when join is set as miter. Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored. Refer to MDN [miterLimit][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit

markLine.data.1.name.desc: Name of the marker, which will display as a label.

markLine.data.1.x.desc: X position according to container, in pixel.

markLine.data.1.y.desc: Y position according to container, in pixel.

markLine.data.1.value.desc: Label value, which can be ignored.

markLine.data.1.symbol.desc:
Symbol of ending point. Icon types provided by ECharts includes 'circle', 'rect', 'roundRect', 'triangle', 'diamond', 'pin', 'arrow', 'none' It can be set to an image with 'image://url' , in which URL is the link to an image, or dataURI of an image. An image URL example: 

    'image://http://xxx.xxx.xxx/a/b.png'
    

A dataURI example: 

    'image://data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAQAMQAAORHHOVSKudfOulrSOp3WOyDZu6QdvCchPGolfO0o/XBs/fNwfjZ0frl3/zy7////wAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACH5BAkAABAALAAAAAAQABAAAAVVICSOZGlCQAosJ6mu7fiyZeKqNKToQGDsM8hBADgUXoGAiqhSvp5QAnQKGIgUhwFUYLCVDFCrKUE1lBavAViFIDlTImbKC5Gm2hB0SlBCBMQiB0UjIQA7'
    

Icons can be set to arbitrary vector path via 'path://' in ECharts. As compared with a raster image, vector paths prevent jagging and blurring when scaled, and have better control over changing colors. The size of the vector icon will be adapted automatically. Refer to [SVG PathData][0] for more information about the format of the path. You may export vector paths from tools like Adobe For example: 

    'path://M30.9,53.2C16.8,53.2,5.3,41.7,5.3,27.6S16.8,2,30.9,2C45,2,56.4,13.5,56.4,27.6S45,53.2,30.9,53.2z M30.9,3.5C17.6,3.5,6.8,14.4,6.8,27.6c0,13.3,10.8,24.1,24.101,24.1C44.2,51.7,55,40.9,55,27.6C54.9,14.4,44.1,3.5,30.9,3.5z M36.9,35.8c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H36c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1V35.8z M27.8,35.8 c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H27c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1L27.8,35.8L27.8,35.8z'
    

[0]: http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG/paths.html#PathData

markLine.data.1.symbolSize.desc: ending point symbol size. It can be set to single numbers like 10, or use an array to represent width and height. For example, [20, 10] means symbol width is 20, and height is10.

markLine.data.1.symbolRotate.desc: Rotate degree of ending point symbol. The negative value represents clockwise. Note that when symbol is set to be 'arrow' in markLine, symbolRotate value will be ignored, and compulsively use tangent angle.

markLine.data.1.symbolKeepAspect.desc: Whether to keep aspect for symbols in the form of path://.

markLine.data.1.symbolOffset.desc: Offset of ending point symbol relative to original position. By default, symbol will be put in the center position of data. But if symbol is from user-defined vector path or image, you may not expect symbol to be in center. In this case, you may use this attribute to set offset to default position. It can be in absolute pixel value, or in relative percentage value. For example, [0, '-50%'] means to move upside side position of symbol height. It can be used to make the arrow in the bottom to be at data position when symbol is pin.

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.desc: Line style of this data item, which will be merged with lineStyle of starting point and ending point.

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.color.desc:
Line color. 

> Supports setting as solid color using > rgb(255,255,255)> , > rgba(255,255,255,1)> , > #fff> , etc. Also supports setting as gradient color and pattern fill, see [> option.color][0]>  for details 

[0]: #color

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.type.desc:
line type. Possible values are: 

* 'solid'

* 'dotted'

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.dashOffset.desc:

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.cap.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are: 

* 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
* 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
* 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN [lineCap][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.join.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet. Possible values are: 

* 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
* 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
* 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the miterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN [lineJoin][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.miterLimit.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when join is set as miter. Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored. Refer to MDN [miterLimit][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.curveness.desc: Edge curvature, which supports value from 0 to 1. The larger the value, the greater the curvature.

markLine.data.1.label.desc: Label of this data item, which will be merged with label of starting point and ending point.

markLine.data.1.label.position.desc:
Positions of labels can be:

markLine.data.1.blur.label.borderWidth.desc: Border width of the text fragment.

markLine.data.1.blur.label.borderType.desc:
the text fragment border type. Possible values are: 

* 'solid'
* 'dashed'
* 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array][0] of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible. For example： 

    {
    
    borderType: [5, 10],
    
    borderDashOffset: 5
    }
    



[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray

markLine.data.1.blur.label.borderDashOff.desc:

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset

markLine.data.1.blur.label.borderRadius.desc: Border radius of the text fragment.

markLine.data.1.blur.label.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example: 

* padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]: represents padding of [top, right, bottom, left].
* padding: 4: represents padding: [4, 4, 4, 4].
* padding: [3, 4]: represents padding: [3, 4, 3, 4].

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

markLine.data.1.blur.label.overflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when width is set. 

* 'truncate' Truncate the text and trailing with ellipsis.
* 'break' Break by word
* 'breakAll' Break by character.

markLine.data.1.blur.label.ellipsis.desc: Ellipsis to be displayed when overflow is set to truncate.

markLine.data.1.blur.label.lineOverflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow on height. 

* 'truncate' Truncate the overflow lines.

Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor). Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding. width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice. Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

markLine.animationThreshold.desc: Whether to set graphic number threshold to animation. Animation will be disabled when graphic number is larger than threshold.

markArea.desc: Used to mark an area in chart. For example, mark a time interval.

markArea.silent.desc: Whether to ignore mouse events. Default value is false, for triggering and responding to mouse events.

markArea.label.position.desc:
Label position. **Followings are the options:*** [x, y] Use relative percentage, or absolute pixel values to represent position of label relative to top-left corner of bounding box. For example: 

      // Absolute pixel values
      position: [10, 10],
      // Relative percentage
      position: ['50%', '50%']
